conclusion: Understanding the self-induction phenomenon in the circuit diagram.
Self-induction occurs when a current flows through a coil, and the induced voltage opposes the current, causing it to decrease over time.
Resistance of the lamp is 6.0Ω, fixed resistor is 2.0Ω, voltage between A and B is 6.0V.
Switch S was originally closed, circuit was in steady state at t1 = 1.0×10^-3s.
Current I displayed by the sensor before and after t1 is shown in Figure B.
Switch S is closed, circuit is in steady state, current I is 1.5A.
When S is opened, current I decreases over time, current I is 0.5A at t1 = 1.0×10^-3s.
Resistance RL of coil L can be calculated using Ohm's law: RL = U/I = 6.0V/0.5A = 12Ω.
Resistance RL of coil L is 12Ω.
